articles.headline: Rubin Leaving Citigroup; Smith Barney for Sale
articles.snippet: The announcement that former Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin will step down came as Citigroup was in talks to sell an interest in its brokerage unit to Morgan Stanley.
articles.abstract: The announcement that former Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin will step down came as Citigroup was in talks to sell an interest in its brokerage unit to Morgan Stanley.
articles.lead_paragraph: Citigroup signaled a breakup of its unwieldy financial supermarket model with a possible deal to sell a share of its prized retail brokerage business to Morgan Stanley, said several people with knowledge of the discussions, underscoring the enormous problems the bank continues to confront even after receiving taxpayer bailout funds.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Louise Story

articles.headline: When Cash Is Scarce, There’s Comfort in Miles
articles.snippet: It’s time to appreciate and evaluate your frequent flier and other rewards programs.
articles.abstract: It’s time to appreciate and evaluate your frequent flier and other rewards programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: For most of us, any summary of our investment performance in 2008 is likely to be depressing. But there’s another personalized annual report that’s worth viewing each January, and this one may offer happier news  of free beach vacations or extra money to pay your bills.

articles.headline: Egyptians Seethe Over Gaza, and Their Leaders Feel Heat
articles.snippet: Public opinions and governments in the Arab world, particularly Egypt, are at odds over the war.
articles.abstract: Public opinions and governments in the Arab world, particularly Egypt, are at odds over the war.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  Inside Al Azhar Mosque, a 1,000-year-old center of religious learning, the preacher was railing on Friday against Jews. Outside were rows of riot police officers backed by water cannons and dozens of plainclothes officers, there to prevent worshipers from charging into the street to protest against the war in Gaza.

articles.headline: Lacking Airlines, Small Cities’ Economies Suffer
articles.snippet: Small cities in 25 states — almost 100 communities in all — have lost commercial air service in the last two years for a variety of reasons.
articles.abstract: Small cities in 25 states — almost 100 communities in all — have lost commercial air service in the last two years for a variety of reasons.
articles.lead_paragraph: Santa Fe, N.M., lost its airline service a year ago, and its tourism-centered economy has definitely felt the pinch. “Either people come through a different airport, or they plain don’t come,” said the airport’s manager, Jim Montman.

articles.headline: In India, Crisis Pairs With Fraud
articles.snippet: India’s credit crisis helped expose the Satyam fraud case.
articles.abstract: India’s credit crisis helped expose the Satyam fraud case.
articles.lead_paragraph: “It is with deep regret, and tremendous burden that I am carrying on my conscience, that I would like to bring the following facts to your notice.”

articles.headline: Iran Moved Billions via U.S. Banks
articles.snippet: Authorities suspect some of the money may have been used to finance Iran’s nuclear and missile programs.
articles.abstract: Authorities suspect some of the money may have been used to finance Iran’s nuclear and missile programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Iranian banks illegally shifted billions of dollars through American financial institutions in recent years, and authorities suspect some of the money may have been used to finance Iran’s nuclear and missile programs.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and John Eligon

articles.headline: New Description of Timing on Madoff’s Confession
articles.snippet: Bernard L. Madoff remained free on bail as questions arose about when he told his brother Peter B. Madoff, the firm’s chief compliance officer, of his Ponzi scheme.
articles.abstract: Bernard L. Madoff remained free on bail as questions arose about when he told his brother Peter B. Madoff, the firm’s chief compliance officer, of his Ponzi scheme.
articles.lead_paragraph: Peter B. Madoff, the younger brother and longtime business partner of Bernard L. Madoff, has said that his brother disclosed his huge fraud scheme to him the evening before confessing to his sons, according to people briefed on the chronology of the scandal.

articles.headline: For Arab Clan, Days of Agony in a Cross-Fire
articles.snippet: Few families have suffered the wrath of the Israeli military as calamitously as the Samounis.
articles.abstract: Few families have suffered the wrath of the Israeli military as calamitously as the Samounis.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA  Israel’s attack has razed buildings and upended families in much of crowded Gaza. But few neighborhoods suffered more than Zeitoun, a district of eastern Gaza City. And few families felt the wrath of the Israeli military more than the Samounis.
articles.byline: By Taghreed El-Khodary and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: Family Mainstay to Move In to White House
articles.snippet: Marian Robinson, the mother-in-law of President-elect Barack Obama, is known as loving and tough-minded.
articles.abstract: Marian Robinson, the mother-in-law of President-elect Barack Obama, is known as loving and tough-minded.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Over the years, several presidents have been forced to ponder the delicate (and sometimes unpleasant) question of whether to move the in-laws into the White House.

articles.headline: At Key Moment, Diverse G.O.P. Leadership Choice
articles.snippet: In an increasingly diverse country, the Republican Party is considering two black candidates for chairman.
articles.abstract: In an increasingly diverse country, the Republican Party is considering two black candidates for chairman.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As the nation is on the verge of inaugurating its first black president, the Republican Party is facing a telling choice: whether to elect its first black chairman.

articles.headline: A Gaza War Full of Traps and Trickery
articles.snippet: The grinding urban battle unfolding in the densely populated Gaza Strip is a war of new tactics and quick adaptation.
articles.abstract: The grinding urban battle unfolding in the densely populated Gaza Strip is a war of new tactics and quick adaptation.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM  The grinding urban battle unfolding in the densely populated Gaza Strip is a war of new tactics, quick adaptation and lethal tricks.

articles.headline: Public Servant’s Private Stint at Issue in Cabinet Hearings
articles.snippet: Republicans plan to press Eric Holder, the attorney general nominee, about his past work as a high-priced Washington lawyer.
articles.abstract: Republicans plan to press Eric Holder, the attorney general nominee, about his past work as a high-priced Washington lawyer.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Chiquita was facing the prospect of federal charges for paying protection money to Colombian terrorists to safeguard its banana crops, and the company needed help. It turned to Eric H. Holder Jr., an elite Washington lawyer well versed in the ways of the Justice Department.

articles.headline: Detroit Goes for Electric Cars, but Will Drivers?
articles.snippet: Ford and other carmakers are betting billions on electric cars despite questions about consumer demand for them.
articles.abstract: Ford and other carmakers are betting billions on electric cars despite questions about consumer demand for them.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich.  Inside the Ford Motor Company, it was called Project M  to build a prototype of a totally electric, battery-powered car in just six months.

articles.headline: At McDonald’s, the Happiest Meal Is Hot Profits
articles.snippet: McDonald’s has managed to sustain its momentum even as the economy and the restaurant industry as a whole are struggling.
articles.abstract: McDonald’s has managed to sustain its momentum even as the economy and the restaurant industry as a whole are struggling.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tinton Falls, N.J.

articles.headline: Beyond the Boldface Names in the IndyMac Deal
articles.snippet: Investors have sued Silar Advisors, a partner in the IndyMac bid, over its handling of a portfolio of properties.
articles.abstract: Investors have sued Silar Advisors, a partner in the IndyMac bid, over its handling of a portfolio of properties.
articles.lead_paragraph: ON New Year’s Eve, as investors everywhere celebrated the end of an awful year, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced some happy news. A consortium of seven investors had agreed to pay $13.9 billion for IndyMac, the California savings bank and mortgage lender that was seized by the government last July.

articles.headline: A Software Populist Who Doesn’t Do Windows
articles.snippet: A version of the Linux operating system called Ubuntu represents the fastest-growing threat to Microsoft in developed countries.
articles.abstract: A version of the Linux operating system called Ubuntu represents the fastest-growing threat to Microsoft in developed countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: THEY’RE either hapless pests or the very people capable of overthrowing Windows. Take your pick.

articles.headline: As Troops Enter Gaza City, Israel Sees an Opening
articles.snippet: Senior Israeli officials said they believed that the Hamas military wing was beginning to crack and that Hamas leaders inside Gaza were looking for a cease-fire.
articles.abstract: Senior Israeli officials said they believed that the Hamas military wing was beginning to crack and that Hamas leaders inside Gaza were looking for a cease-fire.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM  Israeli troops pushed into a heavily populated area of Gaza City from the south on Sunday in fierce fighting, and senior Israeli officials said for the first time in the two-week-old war that they believed that the Hamas military wing was beginning to crack and that Hamas leaders inside Gaza were looking for a cease-fire.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Ethan Bronner

articles.headline: Let’s Invent an iTunes for News
articles.snippet: If print media outlets want to find a new business model, the music industry is worth studying.
articles.abstract: If print media outlets want to find a new business model, the music industry is worth studying.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last Tuesday, iTunes, Apple’s ubiquitous online music store that sold more than 2.4 billion tracks last year alone, changed its own tune, announcing that songs would no longer be sold with copying restrictions and that they would be available at various prices.

articles.headline: Hollywood Finds Headaches in Its Big Bet on 3-D
articles.snippet: Studios have aggressively embraced the technology, but mass market 3-D releases are not tenable without expensive upgrades to projection equipment at the multiplex.
articles.abstract: Studios have aggressively embraced the technology, but mass market 3-D releases are not tenable without expensive upgrades to projection equipment at the multiplex.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  The imminent full-bore return to 3-D filmmaking, upon which the movie industry is placing many of its hopes, is in danger of becoming Hollywood’s latest flub.

articles.headline: S.E.C. Choice Is Sued Over a Merger of Regulators
articles.snippet: Mary L. Schapiro, President-elect Barack Obama’s choice to lead the S.E.C., has been accused of making misleading statements to quickly complete a merger of regulatory bodies.
articles.abstract: Mary L. Schapiro, President-elect Barack Obama’s choice to lead the S.E.C., has been accused of making misleading statements to quickly complete a merger of regulatory bodies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Mary L. Schapiro, who appears this week at a confirmation hearing on her selection to head the Securities and Exchange Commission, has been accused in two lawsuits of making misleading statements to quickly complete a merger of regulatory organizations after which she received a 57 percent raise in her pay.

articles.headline: The High Security Risk Attached to Obama’s Belt
articles.snippet: Security experts and lawyers can come up with plenty of reasons for Barack Obama to surrender his beloved BlackBerry.
articles.abstract: Security experts and lawyers can come up with plenty of reasons for Barack Obama to surrender his beloved BlackBerry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Why can’t the most powerful person in the world keep his BlackBerry?

articles.headline: Crisis Imperils 2-State Plan, Shifting a Balance
articles.snippet: Officials in Egypt and Jordan fear they will be pressed to absorb Palestinian populations beyond their borders.
articles.abstract: Officials in Egypt and Jordan fear they will be pressed to absorb Palestinian populations beyond their borders.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  With every image of the dead in Gaza inflaming people across the Arab world, Egyptian and Jordanian officials are worried that they see a fundamental tenet of the Middle East peace process slipping away: the so-called two-state solution, an independent Palestinian state coexisting with Israel.

articles.headline: New Cars Arrive, Courting Few Buyers
articles.snippet: Many of the new models were in development a few years ago, when the industry was on much stronger footing.
articles.abstract: Many of the new models were in development a few years ago, when the industry was on much stronger footing.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The prolonged slump in vehicle sales has barely slowed car companies from blitzing the market with new models.

articles.headline: Obama Looks to History for Economic Message
articles.snippet: Barack Obama is learning from predecessors as he seeks to shape public attitudes about the economic downturn.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama is learning from predecessors as he seeks to shape public attitudes about the economic downturn.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  It is still a week before he takes office, yet President-elect Barack Obama is everywhere: on the Sunday talk shows, on radio and YouTube, on Capitol Hill, drawing on the techniques he employed during the campaign and lessons from predecessors as he seeks to shape public attitudes about the economic downturn.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Obama Reluctant to Look Into Bush Programs
articles.snippet: Barack Obama indicated that he was unlikely to authorize a broad inquiry into Bush administration programs like domestic eavesdropping.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama indicated that he was unlikely to authorize a broad inquiry into Bush administration programs like domestic eavesdropping.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President-elect Barack Obama signaled in an interview broadcast Sunday that he was unlikely to authorize a broad inquiry into Bush administration programs like domestic eavesdropping or the treatment of terrorism suspects.
articles.byline: By David Johnston and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Push on Immigration Crimes Is Said to Shift Focus
articles.snippet: Federal judges and prosecutors say immigration cases are overloading the court system and eroding morale.
articles.abstract: Federal judges and prosecutors say immigration cases are overloading the court system and eroding morale.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAREDO, Tex.  Inside a courthouse just north of the Rio Grande, federal judges mete out prison sentences to throngs of 40 to 60 illegal immigrants at a time. The accused, mostly from Central America, Brazil and Mexico, wear rough travel clothes that speak of arduous journeys: flannel shirts, sweat suits, jeans and running shoes or work boots.

articles.headline: Citi Is Urged to Replace Its Chairman
articles.snippet: In an effort to restore confidence, federal regulators are pressing the bank to replace Winfried F. W. Bischoff.
articles.abstract: In an effort to restore confidence, federal regulators are pressing the bank to replace Winfried F. W. Bischoff.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal banking regulators are pressing Citigroup to shake up its board and replace its chairman, Winfried F. W. Bischoff, in an effort to restore confidence in the beleaguered financial giant.
